paper_authors: Allen, M. W.; Baines, S.
paper_title: Manipulating the symbolic meaning of meat to encourage greater acceptance of fruits and vegetables and less proclivity for red and white meat
intervention_description: Informed participants that previous research had found that people who consume more meat endorse hierarchy and dominance values, whereas people who consume more fruits and vegetables reject hierarchy and dominance values.
sample_description: residents of a moderate size city in Australia
outcome_description: Percentage of participants who reduced red meat consumption

paper_authors: Amiot, C. E.; El Hajj Boutros, G.; Sukhanova, K.; Karelis, A. D.
paper_title: Testing a novel multicomponent intervention to reduce meat consumption in young men
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, perspective taking, goal pursuit, norms
intervention_description: Participants received a presentation on declining meat consumption trends in Canada since 1980 and the negative health, animal welfare, and environmental impacts of meat consumption (including PETA videos). They completed a mind attribution task writing about a cow's thoughts and feelings, received practical tips for planning meat-free meals and making substitutions, and set a monthly goal to reduce, maintain, or increase their meat consumption. Text messages provided ongoing reinforcement with educational information, benefit reminders, and recipe links., Text-messaging reinforcement of the informational and self-monitoring components. The messages sent upbeat and educational information that reminded participants of the benefits of reducing meat consumption and provided them with additional tips and links to recipes.
sample_description: university students
outcome_description: Total meat consumption over two weekdays and one weekend day

paper_authors: Anderson, J.
paper_title: An experimental investigation of the impact of video media on pork consumption
intervention_description: Participants watched a video about pigs in animal agriculture on a tablet.
control_description: Control participants were not exposed to a video, but it was not a truly neutral control condition, in that the canopy used for the study was covered in graphic images of farm animals
sample_description: presumably mostly university students from the US east and west coast
outcome_description: Frequency of pork consumption over the past 30 days

paper_authors: Anderson, J.
paper_title: An experimental investigation of the impact of video media on pork consumption
intervention_description: Participants watched a 360 degrees video about pigs in animal agriculture. They wore Samsung headsets, which allow viewers to pan in any direction for the duration of each frame.
control_description: Control participants were not exposed to a video, but it was not a truly neutral control condition, in that the canopy used for the study was covered in graphic images of farm animals
sample_description: presumably mostly university students from the US east and west coast
outcome_description: Frequency of pork consumption over the past 30 days

paper_authors: Anderson, E. C.; Feldman Barrett, L.
paper_title: Affective beliefs influence the experience of eating meat
intervention_description: Humane farm description of the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was raised on a farm that focused on animal welfare. The animals were allowed to roam in grassy outdoor pastures where they could graze and exercise. The animals were not isolated so were able to engage in social behaviors with other pigs."
sample_description: Northeastern undergraduate students
outcome_description: Likelihood of eating sampled pork again

paper_authors: Anderson, E. C.; Feldman Barrett, L.
paper_title: Affective beliefs influence the experience of eating meat
intervention_description: Factory farm description for the ham sampled by participants: "This ham was produced at a factory farm that focused on production. The animals were confined to concrete indoor pens where they were unable to lie down or go outside. The animals were isolated so could not engage in social behaviors with other pigs."
sample_description: Northeastern undergraduate students
outcome_description: Likelihood of eating sampled pork again

paper_authors: Bertolaso, C.
paper_title: Investigating the effectiveness of message framing and regulatory fit in increasing positive animal attitude and reducing animal products consumption. a study for animal equality
intervention_description: Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Promotion-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan saves 200 animals per year").
sample_description: English-speaking non-vegan followers of Animal Equality
outcome_description: Frequency of animal product consumption (poultry, fish, beef, pork, eggs, dairy) during the past week

paper_authors: Bertolaso, C.
paper_title: Investigating the effectiveness of message framing and regulatory fit in increasing positive animal attitude and reducing animal products consumption. a study for animal equality
intervention_description: Facebook posts showing what farmed animals endure in factory farms. Prevention-focused framing of the outcome variable (e.g., "each vegan prevents 270 animals per year from being killed").
sample_description: English-speaking non-vegan followers of Animal Equality
outcome_description: Frequency of animal product consumption (poultry, fish, beef, pork, eggs, dairy) during the past week

intervention_description: Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing only chickens, and how to go vegetarian.
sample_description: young individuals at the Warped Tour Music Festival in a variety of cities in the northeastern U.S and students at colleges and universities in the Boston, Philadelphia, and Dallas regions.
outcome_description: Number of meals in a typical week that include fish

paper_authors: Cooney, N.
paper_title: What elements make a vegetarian leaflet more effective?
intervention_mechanism: factual, norms, negative emotional, goal pursuit
intervention_description: Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing only chickens, and how to go vegetarian.
sample_description: young individuals at the Warped Tour Music Festival in a variety of cities in the northeastern U.S and students at colleges and universities in the Boston, Philadelphia, and Dallas regions.
outcome_description: Number of meals in a typical week that include eggs

paper_authors: Cooney, N.
paper_title: What elements make a vegetarian leaflet more effective?
intervention_mechanism: factual, norms, negative emotional, goal pursuit
intervention_description: Booklet focusing primarily on health benefits, discussing only chickens, and how to go vegetarian.
sample_description: young individuals at the Warped Tour Music Festival in a variety of cities in the northeastern U.S and students at colleges and universities in the Boston, Philadelphia, and Dallas regions.
outcome_description: Average number of meals in a typical week that include animal products (red meat, poultry, fish, eggs)

paper_authors: Rocha Possidónio da Silva, C.
paper_title: Am I too cute to eat? The effect of cuteness appeal on the promotion of a more plant-based diet
intervention_mechanism: origin of animal product, positive emotional
intervention_description: A picture of a high-cuteness pig together with three different pork-meals.
control_description: A white frame together with three different pork-meals.
sample_description: predominantly urban dwelling Portuguese-speaking omnivores
outcome_description: Valence of the pork meal shown in an image

paper_authors: Doebel, S.; Gabriel, S.; The Humane League
paper_title: Does encouraging the public to “eat vegan,” “eat vegetarian,” “eat less meat,” or “cut out or cut back on” meat and other animal products lead to the most diet change?
intervention_mechanism: factual, norms, negative emotional, origin of animal product, authority/expertise
intervention_description: A booklet that discussed the cruelty of animal farming and the health benefits of of removing animal products from one's diet and encouraged the reader to go vegan.
sample_description: respondents on college campuses
outcome_description: Number of meals that contain beef or pork in a typical week

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model
intervention_description: Participants watched a 7-minute video that informed viewers of the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) and suggested easy ways to reduce their meat consumption to increase perceived efficacy.
sample_description: US residents who consume meat at least 7 times per week
outcome_description: Intention to eat less meat in the next six months

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model
intervention_description: Participants watched a 7-minute video that informed viewers of the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) and suggested easy ways to reduce their meat consumption to increase perceived efficacy.
sample_description: US residents who consume meat at least 7 times per week
outcome_description: Average attitude towards changing diet based on seven dimensions (e.g., bad/good, negative/positive, harmful/beneficial)

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model
intervention_description: Participants watched a 7-minute video that informed viewers of the negative health effects of high meat consumption (high threat) and suggested easy ways to reduce their meat consumption to increase perceived efficacy.
sample_description: US residents who consume meat at least 7 times per week
outcome_label: reported meat consumption in the past week
outcome_description: Change in meat consumption over the past seven days

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model

sample_description: US residents who consume meat at least 7 times per week
outcome_label: change in reported meat consumption frequency
outcome_description: Change in meat frequency over the past seven days

paper_authors: Fehrenbach, K. S.
paper_title: Designing messages to reduce meat consumption: A test of the extended parallel process model

paper_authors: Loy, L. S.; Wieber, F.; Gollwitzer, P. M.; Oettingen, G.
paper_title: Supporting sustainable food consumption: Mental contrasting with implementation intentions (mcii) aligns intentions and behavior
intervention_description: Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption.
sample_description: participants from a German university
outcome_label: reduction in meat consumption compared to baseline
outcome_description: Change in weight of meat consumed for each meal

paper_authors: Loy, L. S.; Wieber, F.; Gollwitzer, P. M.; Oettingen, G.
paper_title: Supporting sustainable food consumption: Mental contrasting with implementation intentions (mcii) aligns intentions and behavior
intervention_description: Participants read a text providing information about meat consumption, adressing environmental consequences of meat consumption and other arguments for reduced consumption. Participants completed a procedure for mental contrasting with implementation intentions in which individuals wrote down (1) a personal goal, (2) positive outcomes of goal achievement, the best outcome, and respective associations, (3) obstacles of goal achievement, their two main obstacles, and respective associations, and finally (4) four IIs addressing their two main obstacles.
sample_description: participants from a German university
outcome_label: reduction in meat consumption compared to baseline
outcome_description: Change in weight of meat consumed for each meal

paper_authors: Sparkman, G.; Walton, G. M.
paper_title: Dynamic norms promote sustainable behavior, even if it is counternormative
intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that, in the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have now started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."
sample_description: US adults
outcome_description: Interest in eating less meat

paper_authors: Sparkman, G.; Walton, G. M.
paper_title: Dynamic norms promote sustainable behavior, even if it is counternormative
intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."
sample_description: US adults
outcome_description: Interest in eating less meat

paper_authors: Sparkman, G.; Walton, G. M.
paper_title: Dynamic norms promote sustainable behavior, even if it is counternormative
intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Some people are starting to limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that, over the last 5 years, 30% of Americans have started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people have changed their behavior and begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would."
sample_description: customers waiting in line at a café on the Stanford campus
outcome_description: Percentage of purchased meals containing meat

paper_authors: Sparkman, G.; Walton, G. M.
paper_title: Dynamic norms promote sustainable behavior, even if it is counternormative
intervention_description: Partcipants saw the message: "Some people limit how much meat they eat. This is true both nationally and here at Stanford. Specifically, recent research has shown that 30% of Americans make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people eat less meat than they otherwise would."
sample_description: customers waiting in line at a café on the Stanford campus
outcome_description: Percentage of purchased meals containing meat

paper_authors: Animal Charity Evaluators
paper_title: 2013 humane education study
intervention_description: Participants attended a presentation that documents the abuse on factory farms, is pro animal, and asked students to reduce or eliminate animal meat and products from their diets. Focus was mainly on the ethical implications of factory farming, and also touched on health and environmental consequences.
control_description: Participants from a different class that did not attend the presentation.
sample_description: high school and college students
outcome_description: Frequency of red meat consumption in the last 7 days

paper_authors: Mercy for Animals
paper_title: Welfare reforms and meat consumption
intervention_description: Participants read a pork policy article that discusses the policy commitments of major companies to transition the pigs in their supply chains from gestation crates to crate-free environments.
control_description: Participants read a policy article that discusses the policy commitments of major companies to transition from plastic bags to paper bags.
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Intention to change pork consumption over the next few months

paper_authors: Mercy for Animals
paper_title: Welfare reforms and meat consumption
intervention_description: Participants read a pork legislation article that discusses the legislation implemented by many U.S. states banning the use of gestation crates.
control_description: Participants read a legislation article that discusses the legislation implemented by many U.S. states banning the use of plastic bags.
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Intention to change pork consumption over the next few months

paper_authors: Mercy for Animals
paper_title: Do online videos of farmed animal cruelty change people’s diets and attitudes?
intervention_description: Participants saw a pro-vegetarian Facebook and that, after clicking on it, directed them to a Mercy for Animals landing page with a video on cruelty to farm animals called Farm to Fridge.
control_description: Participants saw a pro-vegetarian Facebook and that, after clicking on it, directed them to a Mercy for Animals landing page with a video on fighting tropical diseases.
sample_description: Facebook users (recruited via targeted ads)
outcome_label: meat consumption in past two days
outcome_description: Total pork, beef, chicken and turkey, and fish and seafood servings in the past two days

paper_authors: Mercy for Animals

control_description: Participants saw a pro-vegetarian Facebook and that, after clicking on it, directed them to a Mercy for Animals landing page with a video on fighting tropical diseases.
sample_description: Facebook users (recruited via targeted ads)
outcome_label: animal product consumption in the past two days

paper_authors: Mathur, M. B.; Peacock, J. R.; Robinson, T. N.; Gardner, C. D.
paper_title: Effectiveness of a theory-informed documentary to reduce consumption of meat and animal products: Three randomized controlled experiments
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, norms, origin of animal product, goal pursuit
intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.
control_description: Participants watched a 20-min TED talk by Brené Brown entitled “Listening to shame”, a generic motivational speech that encouraged listeners to embrace the experience of feeling vulnerable.
sample_description: US-based participants
outcome_label: reported meat consumption in the past week
outcome_description: Total weight of animal product consumption over the past week

paper_authors: Caso, G.; Rizzo, G.; Migliore, G.; Vecchio, R.
paper_title: Loss framing effect on reducing excessive red and processed meat consumption: Evidence from Italy
intervention_description: Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Based on estimates from the Global Disease Burden Project, the WHO states that >34.000 cancer deaths per year worldwide are attributable to high intake of processed meat, while the total number of deaths attributable to a diet rich in red meat was 644.000."
sample_description: stratified Italian sample of meat eaters
outcome_description: Percentage of participants intending to consume less red and processed meat in the future

paper_authors: Caso, G.; Rizzo, G.; Migliore, G.; Vecchio, R.
paper_title: Loss framing effect on reducing excessive red and processed meat consumption: Evidence from Italy
intervention_description: Participants read that "The World Health Organization (WHO) classified red meat as a possible carcinogen, meaning it could cause cancer. Just 50 g of red or processed meat consumed in a regular daily diet can increase cancer incidence by 18%. It is known that high consumption of red or processed meat can increase the risk of other chronic diseases (such as stroke and type II diabetes)."
sample_description: stratified Italian sample of meat eaters
outcome_description: Percentage of participants intending to consume less red and processed meat in the future

intervention_description: Participants attended a moral philosophy course in which various controversial topics, including meat eating, were discussed. They read Alastair Norcross' Puppies, Pigs, and People. Participants were also instructed to reflect on their views as an additional manipulation.

outcome_description: Agreement with 'To what extent do you find meat-eating morally acceptable or morally wrong?'

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Bertolotti, M.; Catellani, P.
paper_title: Informational and emotional daily messages to reduce red and processed meat consumption
intervention_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages that cited the health and environmental outcomes of red processed meat cosumption. The information was presented in a way that was meant to evoke anticipated regret (e.g., “If you eat an excessive amount of red/processed meat, you could feel regret for not protecting your health from cancer and the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases”).
control_description: Participants received daily persuasive messages describing the health and environmental consequences of eating sugar.
sample_description: undergraduates of the Catholic University of Milan
outcome_description: Total number of processed red meat portions weighted by portion size

The leaf rating that accompanies each menu item represented the sustainability of each item.

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Climatarian diet significantly reducing or eliminating red meat from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Livestock agriculture contributes up to a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions, with almost all of this coming from cows and sheep. In Australia, producing 1 kg of beef requires an average of 15,182 L of water. Furthermore, livestock agriculture drives 80% of deforestation worldwide, using up a third of the world s ice-free land. Adopting a Climatarian diet is a powerfulway to reduce your impact on the climate. Shifting to a Climatarian diet will reduce your carbon footprint by approximately 1000 kg of CO2 every year, or the equivalent of driving from Perth to Brisbane."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is the ‘One step for the animals diet' eliminating chicken from our diets. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. The vast majorityof these animals today are birds. It takes more than 200 chickens to provide the same number of meals as one cow.If we can convince someone to stop eating birds, they would go from being responsible for the factory farming and slaughtering of more than two dozen land animals per year to fewer than one. Furthermore, while most cows and sheep raised in Australia spend most of their life grazing, the vast majority of chickens are raised in crowded factory farms."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Reducetarian diet reducing the amount of meat that we eat. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factoryfarms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a reductionist diet is appealing because not everyone is willing to follow an all-or-nothing diet. It is also a powerful way to reduce animal cruelty. For example, halving your meat consumption will spare around 50 innocent lives every year. This includes about 13 land animals, and 37 fish and shellfish every year."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read:  "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Vegetarian diet eliminating all meat and fish from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a vegetarian diet is the most powerful way to object to animal cruelty, and by doing so, you will spare approximately 100 animal lives (25 land animals and 75 fish and shellfish) every year."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factoryfarms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a reductionist diet is appealing because not everyone is willing to follow an all-or-nothing diet. It is also a powerful way to reduce animal cruelty. For example, halving your meat consumption will spare around 50 innocent lives every year. This includes about 13 land animals, and 37 fish and shellfish every year."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read:  "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Vegetarian diet eliminating all meat and fish from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a vegetarian diet is the most powerful way to object to animal cruelty, and by doing so, you will spare approximately 100 animal lives (25 land animals and 75 fish and shellfish) every year."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Climatarian diet significantly reducing or eliminating red meat from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Livestock agriculture contributes up to a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions, with almost all of this coming from cows and sheep. In Australia, producing 1 kg of beef requires an average of 15,182 L of water. Furthermore, livestock agriculture drives 80% of deforestation worldwide, using up a third of the world s ice-free land. Adopting a Climatarian diet is a powerfulway to reduce your impact on the climate. Shifting to a Climatarian diet will reduce your carbon footprint by approximately 1000 kg of CO2 every year, or the equivalent of driving from Perth to Brisbane."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake
intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is the ‘One step for the animals diet' eliminating chicken from our diets. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. The vast majorityof these animals today are birds. It takes more than 200 chickens to provide the same number of meals as one cow.If we can convince someone to stop eating birds, they would go from being responsible for the factory farming and slaughtering of more than two dozen land animals per year to fewer than one. Furthermore, while most cows and sheep raised in Australia spend most of their life grazing, the vast majority of chickens are raised in crowded factory farms."
sample_description: University of Melbourne participant pool
outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Piazza, J.; Gregson, R.; Kordoni, A.; Pfeiler, T. M.; Ruby, M. B.; Ellis, D. A.; Sahin, E.; Reith, M.
paper_title: Monitoring a meat-free pledge with smartphones: An experimental study
intervention_description: Participants were invited to take part in a 28-day commitment to eat meat-free and they were given the opportunity to freely opt out of the pledge, by withdrawing from the study, or continue with it, by offering their written consent. Participants were encouraged to “do their best” to try to eat meat-free for the duration of the study.
sample_description: students from Lancaster University (UK), Johannes Gutenberg-University Mainz (Germany), and La Trobe (Australia) and non-students living in Melbourne via targeted Facebook advertisements
outcome_label: food frequency of beef, pork, chicken, turkey, and other meats
outcome_description: Daily consumption of beef, pork, chicken, turkey, and other meats

paper_authors: Schwitzgebel, E.; Cokelet, B.; Singer, P.
paper_title: Students Eat Less Meat After Studying Meat Ethics
intervention_mechanism: negative emotional, factual, origin of animal product
intervention_description: Participants read James Rachels’ article “The Basic Argument for Vegetarianism”. Teaching assistants played the 11-minute vegetarianism advocacy video “What Came Before” that contained factory farm footage. They also presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.
sample_description: University of California philosphy students
outcome_label: ethicality of eating factory farmed meat
outcome_description: Agreement with 'Eating the meat of factory farmed animals is unethical.'

paper_authors: Schwitzgebel, E.; Cokelet, B.; Singer, P.

They also presented both pro and con considerations in their discussion sections, encouraging debate among students.
sample_description: University of California philosphy students
outcome_label: intention to not eat factory farmed meat
outcome_description: Agreement with 'For at least the next month, I will eat no factory farmed meat at all – or if I find it too difficult to stick to that, I will eat it at most once per week.'

paper_authors: Branković, M.; Budžak, A.; Tulić, N.; Janković, J.
paper_title: Effects of experimentally induced self-affirmation on the openness to meat reduction and alternative protein sources
intervention_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their personal experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
control_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of their favorite colors and explained how this color is personally appealing, e.g., to describe an object or context in which it was appealing. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
sample_description: Participants recruited via a passive snowball method on social media.
outcome_description: Average openness to meat reduction measured with five items (e.g. their readiness to reduce meat consumption in the following 6 months)

paper_authors: Branković, M.; Budžak, A.; Tulić, N.; Janković, J.
paper_title: Effects of experimentally induced self-affirmation on the openness to meat reduction and alternative protein sources
intervention_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of 10 values and briefly describe a situation or example that shows how the first-ranked value is reflected in their group experience. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
control_description: Participants were asked to create a ranked list of their favorite colors and explained how this color is personally appealing, e.g., to describe an object or context in which it was appealing. Participants then read a vignette briefly introducing health-related risks of meat consumption (e.g., higher incidence of disease), benefits of decreased consumption, as well as alternative sources of protein, including lab-grown meats.
sample_description: Participants recruited via a passive snowball method on social media.
outcome_description: Average openness to meat reduction measured with five items (e.g. their readiness to reduce meat consumption in the following 6 months)

paper_authors: Venema, T. A. G.; Holm Jensen, N.
paper_title: We meat again: a field study on the moderating role of location-specific consumer preferences in nudging vegetarian option
intervention_description: "Chef’s recommendation" stickers were placed on the vegetarian sandwich bags. One vegetarian sandwich was displayed on a plate at eye-level with the content clearly visible. This plate was accompanied by a sign that read “Kokken anbefaler” (Chef's recommendation) and a brief description of the café’s sustainability goals. All vegetarian sandwiches were placed in first line-of-sight from the typical customer flow direction. The labels on vegetarian sandwiches were slightly more colourful and the bags were closed more aesthetically than meat sandwiches.
sample_description: data points represent food items sold at a restaurant
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian sandwich sales

paper_authors: Guedes, D.; Brazão, V.; Roque, L; Campos, L.; Godinho, C.; Truninger, M.; Vinnari, M.; João Graça, J.
paper_title: Promoting plant-based eating in meat-centric meal contexts: a field study
intervention_description: A 2-day workshop with the canteen kitchen staff on the relevance of promoting plant-based eating, basic principles of plant-based nutritional literacy, and practical demonstrations of how to improve the visual and sensory appeal of plant-based meals was conducted. Posters advertising the "Sustainability Week" initiative were placed in the cafeteria. The menu presented the vegetarian option as the "suggestion of the day" with an increased font size above the meat and fish options.
sample_description: data points represent lunch meals sold at a university cafeteria
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian lunch sales

paper_authors: Winkelmair, A.; Jansen, P.
paper_title: The positive impact of mindfulness interventions on the explicit and implicit affective attitudes toward vegetarian foods
intervention_description: Participants completed a 12-week compassion and cating-based training which consisted of weekly sessions á 75 min and weekly homework assignments. Participants were introduced to a way to offer love to themselves, other people, or animals. Affect dyad situations were applied where partners sit face to face, and one partner contemplates a situation to a specific theme of the main topics. The other partner listens attentively without giving any verbal or non-verbal feedback.
sample_description: students from the University of Regensburg
outcome_description: Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

paper_authors: Winkelmair, A.; Jansen, P.
paper_title: The positive impact of mindfulness interventions on the explicit and implicit affective attitudes toward vegetarian foods
intervention_description: Participants completed a 12-week mindfulness-based stress reduction program that included various elements of meditation: body scan, mindful eating, emphasizing the breath, and sitting and walking meditation training. Every session contained a talk about specific topics such as different forms of meditation and problems that may arise with them. The focus of this mindfulness group was on the rather cognitive elements of mindfulness and its qualities of awareness.
sample_description: students from the University of Regensburg
outcome_description: Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

Affect dyad situations were applied where partners sit face to face, and one partner contemplates a situation to a specific theme of the main topics. The other partner listens attentively without giving any verbal or non-verbal feedback.
sample_description: students from the University of Regensburg
outcome_description: Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

paper_authors: Winkelmair, A.; Jansen, P.
paper_title: The positive impact of mindfulness interventions on the explicit and implicit affective attitudes toward vegetarian foods
intervention_description: Participants completed a 12-week mindfulness-based stress reduction program that included various elements of meditation: body scan, mindful eating, emphasizing the breath, and sitting and walking meditation training. Every session contained a talk about specific topics such as different forms of meditation and problems that may arise with them. The focus of this mindfulness group was on the rather cognitive elements of mindfulness and its qualities of awareness.
sample_description: students from the University of Regensburg
outcome_description: Percentage of participants identifying as vegan or vegetarian

paper_authors: Pohlmann, A.
paper_title: The taste of compassion: Influencing meat attitudes with interhuman and interspecies moral appeals
intervention_description: With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of 15 pretested stock photographs portraying scenes of vulnerability, human connection, care-giving, and displays of emotional distress. The photos pictured female and male adults, as well as children and the elderly, and a range of ethnicities.
control_description: With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of geometric shapes.
sample_description: Residents in the United States.
outcome_description: Percentage of participants selecting a meat entrée out of ten pairs of photographs of popular entrées that can be prepared with meat or in a vegetarian version

paper_authors: Pohlmann, A.
paper_title: The taste of compassion: Influencing meat attitudes with interhuman and interspecies moral appeals
intervention_description: Installation of of visual manipulations under the guise of a photo exhibit at the restaurant. The photographic stimuli were chosen with the following in mind: the connection between human and animal needed to be emphasized by visual overlap between the subjects, suggesting a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude.
sample_description: Visitors of a restaurant near the university campus.
outcome_description: Number of meat menu item sales

paper_authors: Pohlmann, A.
paper_title: The taste of compassion: Influencing meat attitudes with interhuman and interspecies moral appeals
intervention_description: All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. Compassion was primed a slideshow using photographs showing people as having a caring, devoted, and protecting attitude. Participants then reviewed ingredients and nutritional information for the BLT, chicken, and falafel wrap presented in standard FDA tables.
control_description: All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. Participants were presented with a slideshow of geometric shapes. Participants then reviewed ingredients and nutritional information for the BLT, chicken, and falafel wrap presented in standard FDA tables.
sample_description: Participants who took part in a taste test conducted in a university event room.
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing a wrap containing meat (BLT or chicken) over a falafel wrap

paper_authors: Marcone, A. L.; Darmstadt, G. L.; Challamel, G. A.; Mathur, M.; Gardner, C. D.
paper_title: Effects of an educational planetary plate graphic on meat consumption in a Stanford University dining hall: a randomized controlled trial
intervention_description: Signs with a Planetary Health Plate graphic featuring a diet based on the EAT Lancet Planetary Health Diet were posted. The sign included information on top of the sign: “Today, our diets have a large impact on our global ecosystem. In February 2019, scientists collaborated with The Lancet medical journal to establish this realistic diet that maintains both human and planetary health.” And on the bottom of the sign “Modeling your plate like this one builds a healthy diet and a sustainable world”.
sample_description: customers at a Stanford University dining hall
outcome_description: Number of meat-dish servings

paper_authors: Slapø, H. B.; Karevold, K. I.
paper_title: Simple Eco-Labels to Nudge Customers Toward the Most Environmentally Friendly Warm Dishes: An Empirical Study in a Cafeteria Setting
intervention_description: All meat dishes were labeled as “High CO2” dishes, all fish dishes as “Medium CO2”, and all vegetarian as “Low CO2” dishes.
sample_description: customers at the University of Oslo cafeteria
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Slapø, H. B.; Karevold, K. I.
paper_title: Simple Eco-Labels to Nudge Customers Toward the Most Environmentally Friendly Warm Dishes: An Empirical Study in a Cafeteria Setting
intervention_description: The vegetarian dish was labeled with the “Low CO2” sign.
sample_description: customers at the University of Oslo cafeteria
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Slapø, H. B.; Karevold, K. I.
paper_title: Simple Eco-Labels to Nudge Customers Toward the Most Environmentally Friendly Warm Dishes: An Empirical Study in a Cafeteria Setting
intervention_description: The meat dish was labeled with a “High CO2” sign.
sample_description: customers at the University of Oslo cafeteria
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian dish sales

paper_authors: Boronowsky, R. D.; Zhang, A. W.; Stecher, C.; Presley, K.; Mathur, M.; Cleveland, D. A.; Garnett, E.; Wharton, C.; Brown, D.; Meier, A.; Wang, M.; Braverman, I; Jay, J. A.
paper_title: Plant-based default nudges effectively increase the sustainability of catered meals on college campuses: Three randomized controlled trials
intervention_description: Individuals responded to an RSVP survey for an event in which the vegetarian option was the default meal preference.
control_description: Individuals responded to an RSVP survey for an event in which the meat option was the default meal preference.
sample_description: adults over the age of 18 who attended one of our three events held at the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA) and Harvard University
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal selections

paper_authors: Banach, N.; Stel, M
paper_title: Reducing Speciesism: An Intervention to Change People’s Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions
intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.
sample_description: students from the University of Twente
outcome_description: Score on the Speciesism Scale (e.g., morally, animals always count for less than humans)

paper_authors: Banach, N.; Stel, M
paper_title: Reducing Speciesism: An Intervention to Change People’s Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions
intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.
sample_description: students from the University of Twente
outcome_description: Intention to change behaviors that (in)directly harm animals across five categories (e.g., entertainment, experiments, farming)

paper_authors: Banach, N.; Stel, M
paper_title: Reducing Speciesism: An Intervention to Change People’s Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions
intervention_description: A video (2:48 minutes long) was presented which showed a parallel world wherein the roles of humans and animals were reversed. The video presented illustrations of situations in which animals are harmed, but where the humans took the role of the animals and vice versa.

outcome_description: Score on the Speciesism Scale (e.g., morally, animals always count for less than humans)

paper_authors: Gravert, C.; Kurz, V.
paper_title: Nudging à la carte: a field experiment on climate-friendly food choice
intervention_description: The menu listed the daily vegetarian and fish dishes but not the meat dish and a sentence stated that “an option containing meat is available on request.”
control_description: The menu contained, as before, the daily meat and fish options for the whole week, and had an additional sentence stating that “a vegetarian option is available on request.”
sample_description: data points represent lunch meals sold at a restaurant
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian meal selections

paper_authors: Erhard, A.;  Boztuğ, Y.; Lemken, D.
paper_title: How do defaults and framing influence food choice? An intervention aimed at promoting plant-based choice in online menus
intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.
sample_description: Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of times a meal with the plant-based sausage was selected in a mock meal-kit delivery service

paper_authors: Erhard, A.;  Boztuğ, Y.; Lemken, D.
paper_title: How do defaults and framing influence food choice? An intervention aimed at promoting plant-based choice in online menus
intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the sustainable plant-based default condition, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the most sustainable sausage for you”.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.
sample_description: Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of times a meal with the plant-based sausage was selected in a mock meal-kit delivery service

paper_authors: Erhard, A.;  Boztuğ, Y.; Lemken, D.
paper_title: How do defaults and framing influence food choice? An intervention aimed at promoting plant-based choice in online menus
intervention_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. In the tasty plant-based default conditions, the plant-based sausage was selected and a pop-up message said "We have selected the tastiest sausage for you”.
control_description: Each menu had a pre-selected sausage such that one type of sausage was in the electronic shopping cart upon viewing the menu. The baseline condition, in which pork was pre-selected, was used to reflect the real-world status quo.
sample_description: Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of times a meal with the plant-based sausage was selected in a mock meal-kit delivery service

paper_authors: Bianchi, F.; Stewart, C.; Astbury, N. M.; Cook, B.; Aveyard, P.; Jebb, S. A.
paper_title: Replacing meat with alternative plant-based products (RE-MAP): A randomized controlled trial of a multicomponent behavioral intervention to reduce meat consumption
paper_source: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition
intervention_description: The intervention consisted of 4 components: 1) free meat substitutes for the household for 4 weeks; 2) information leaflets about the health and environmental benefits of eating less meat; 3) recipes; and 4) success stories in the form of vignettes of people who reduced their meat intake.
sample_description: volunteers from Oxford, UK from adult-only households recruited from the community through advertisements
outcome_description: Daily meat consumption

paper_authors: Perino, G.; Schwirplies, C.
paper_title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
paper_source: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
intervention_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article advocating a specific reason why reducing meat consumption is recommendable (e.g., "Meat harms your health"). All quotes refer to ‘‘scientific evidence’’ or a ‘‘study’’ without naming the specific source. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.
control_description: Participants read an excerpt from a real newspaper article on sugary drinks at school kiosks and did not contain any reference to meat. Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.
sample_description: German panel participants
outcome_description: Intention to reduce meat consumption by a little or a lot in the coming weeks

paper_authors: Perino, G.; Schwirplies, C.
paper_title: Meaty arguments and fishy effects: Field experimental evidence on the impact of reasons to reduce meat consumption
paper_source: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management

Each quote was followed by an explicit statement with a dietary recommendation taken from the website of the German Nutrition Society.

paper_authors: Çoker, E. N.; Pechey, R.; Frie, K.; Jebb, S. A.; Stewart, C.; Higgs, S.; Cook, B.
paper_title: A dynamic social norm messaging intervention to reduce meat consumption: A randomized cross-over trial in retail store restaurants
intervention_description: The message “More and more [retail store name] customers are choosing our veggie options” appeared in a green circle on the top right corner of the image displayed on the digital boards, covering 1/8th of the screen, and was animated with a small stretching and wobbling effect to draw customers’ attention further. The message was displayed alongside a picture of the vegetarian breakfast option during the breakfast service hours, and a vegetarian main meal during the remaining trading hours.
sample_description: patrons of in-store restaurants of a retail chain in the UK
outcome_description: Percentage of main meals that were plant-based

paper_authors: Çoker, E. N.; Pechey, R.; Frie, K.; Jebb, S. A.; Stewart, C.; Higgs, S.; Cook, B.

paper_authors: Zinn, A. K.; Zhu, O. Y.; Dolnicar, S.
paper_title: Increasing meat-free meal selections: The role of social identity salience and identity-related meal names
intervention_description: Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as a person that cares about environmental sustainability (sustainable social identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you and other people that care about environmental sustainability do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a sustainable halloumi burger and a sustainable falafel burger.
control_description: Participants completed an identity manipulation: Please think of yourself as an individual (personal identity). Please write at least 4–5 sentences (25 words) about the following topic: What are things that you personally do ... often? ... rarely? ... well? ... badly?. Meal name manipulation: the vegetarian burgers were labeled as a sustainable halloumi burger and a sustainable falafel burger.
sample_description: Australian and British Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of participants selecting a vegetarian burger

paper_authors: Zinn, A. K.; Zhu, O. Y.; Dolnicar, S.

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Catellania, P.; Casob, D.; Conner, M.
paper_title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
intervention_description: A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the health condition received messages focused on the health benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g. “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect your health from colon cancer/heart disease/respiratory disease).
sample_description: undergraduate university students attending courses in Psychology in two cities in the North and South of Italy
outcome_description: Number of red and processed meat servings over the previous week

paper_authors: Carfora, V.; Catellania, P.; Casob, D.; Conner, M.
paper_title: How to reduce red and processed meat consumption by daily text messages targeting environment or health benefits
intervention_description: A chatbot was programmed by the researchers to send different daily messages. Participants in the environment condition participants received messages focused on the environmental benefits of eating little red, processed meat (e.g., “If you eat little red and processed meat, you will protect the environment from the release of harmful greenhouse gases/soil acidification/climate change”).

outcome_description: Number of red and processed meat servings over the previous week

paper_authors: Karakaş, N., Jaeger, B.
paper_title: Changes in attitudes toward meat consumption after chatting with a large language model
intervention_description: Participants had an open-ended chat about meat consumption that lasted 5-10 minutes with ChatGPTT-4o. The same initial prompt was entered for all participants: “I want to have a conversation about meat consumption. I currently eat meat. Are there any reasons why I should limit my meat consumption or stop eating meat entirely?”. Participants were given a list of questions they could ask ChatGPT, but were also told that they could decide where to steer the conversation. The provided questions focused on the environment (e.g., “How does meat consumption impact the environment?”), personal health (e.g., “Is it necessary to eat meat to be healthy?”), and animal welfare (e.g., “What percentage of meat in Dutch supermarkets comes from factory farms?”), and also included more generic prompts (e.g., “It would be quite difficult to reduce my meat consumption by a lot. How can I make this easier?”).
sample_description: students recruited in the library of a Dutch university
outcome_description: Average score on the Meat Commitment Scale

paper_authors: Weikertova, S.; Urban, J.
paper_title: Dynamic Norms Do Not Promote Vegetarian Food Preferences: Two Experiments and a Meta-Analysis
intervention_description: Participants received dynamic norm treatment as they were provided information about decreasing meat consumption in non-specific reference groups, and about an increasing demand for vegetarian meals in the specific reference group.
control_description: Participants received unrelated trend information.
sample_description: Participants were Charles University Students obtained through snowball sampling via email lists and facebook posts.
outcome_description: Participants' choice of meatless meals in a choice experiment task including one meat-based and one meatless meal. These meals adapted from university canteens, not labeled,as vegetarian or not, and they had a fixed price.

paper_authors: Rieforth, A.; Theis, H.
paper_title: Nudging to Reduce Meat Consumption: Can Indulgent or Healthy Descriptors Promote Vegetarian Food Choices?
intervention_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options described with indulgent words-phrases such as "soul comforting", "feel good'', ''fresh and crispy''. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.
control_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options, this condition included basic descriptions, and served as a baseline. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.
sample_description: Participants, the majority of whom resided in Europe (88.5%), were recruited through snowball sampling via contacts and social networks.
outcome_description: The recording of the food option that each participant selected in their assigned survey

paper_authors: Rieforth, A.; Theis, H.

control_description: Participants were presented with vegetarian food box options, this condition included basic descriptions, and served as a baseline. Meat food box options had basic descriptions in all conditions.
sample_description: Participants, the majority of whom resided in Europe (88.5%), were recruited through snowball sampling via contacts and social networks.
outcome_description: The recording of the food option that each participant selected in their assigned survey

paper_authors: Anderson, J.
paper_title: “Reduce” Or “Go Veg”? Effects On Meal Choice
intervention_description: Participants watched a video describing the diverse benefits of plant-based eating, showed some mild factory farm footage, and described changing social norms around meat consumption to convey a growing trend. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to reduce their meat consumption.
control_description: Participants watched a video with white text on a dark background describing how to complete the study. Participants were also asked if they would be willing to take a dietary pledge to reduce their meat consumption.
sample_description: Passersby on campus at Carleton University (Ottawa, Ontario, Canada), outside Rooster's Coffeehouse, a small, student-operated café.
outcome_description: Percentage of meatless meal orders

paper_authors: Bryant, C.; Dillard, C.

intervention_description: Students were exposed to a classroom education intervention aiming to reduce animal product consumption. Students saw one of five different presentations with differing focuses, and they answered a survey.
control_description: Students answered an online survey before being exposed to the classroom presentation. This set of students would act as a control group, against which the responses of the treatment group could be compared.
sample_description: Students at schools and colleges in the USA and Canada
outcome_description: Participants' intention to not change their animal product consumption

paper_authors: Aberman, Y.; Plaks, J.
paper_title: When Less is better: Messages that Present Dietary Carbon Emissions Data at the individual (vs. Aggregate) Level Increase Commitment to Sustainable Beef Consumption
intervention_description: Participants read footprint information about the footprint of the entire US beef industry, e.g. “Every day, the beef industry in the US has a water footprint of approximately 128 billion gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 128 billion is more than the number of stars in the Milky Way.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Participants were asked, “In comparison to recent weeks, did you consume more or less beef?”

paper_authors: Aberman, Y.; Plaks, J.
paper_title: When Less is better: Messages that Present Dietary Carbon Emissions Data at the individual (vs. Aggregate) Level Increase Commitment to Sustainable Beef Consumption
intervention_description: Participants read foodprint information, but the same numerical information was scaled to the individual level and adjusted for a single individual, e.g. “A single beef burger, for example, has a water footprint of approximately 450 gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 450 gallons is more than what an average person drinks in two years.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Participants were asked, “In comparison to recent weeks, did you consume more or less beef?”

paper_authors: Aberman, Y.; Plaks, J.
paper_title: When Less is better: Messages that Present Dietary Carbon Emissions Data at the individual (vs. Aggregate) Level Increase Commitment to Sustainable Beef Consumption
intervention_description: Participants read footprint information about the footprint of the entire US beef industry, e.g. “Every day, the beef industry in the US has a water footprint of approximately 128 billion gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 128 billion is more than the number of stars in the Milky Way.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Participants were asked, “In comparison to recent weeks, did you consume more or less beef?”

paper_authors: Aberman, Y.; Plaks, J.
paper_title: When Less is better: Messages that Present Dietary Carbon Emissions Data at the individual (vs. Aggregate) Level Increase Commitment to Sustainable Beef Consumption
intervention_description: Participants read foodprint information, but the same numerical information was scaled to the individual level and adjusted for a single individual, e.g. “A single beef burger, for example, has a water footprint of approximately 450 gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 450 gallons is more than what an average person drinks in two years.”
control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task
sample_description: MTurk participants
outcome_description: Participants were asked, “In comparison to recent weeks, did you consume more or less beef?”

control_description: Participants did not receive any information about food and the environment and instead performed a filler task
sample_description: MTurk participants

paper_authors: Berke, A.; Larson, K.
paper_title: The negative impact of vegetarian and vegan labels: Results from randomized controlled experiments with US consumers
intervention_description: Participants saw menu options without any labels; the choice questions differ in the types of options compared (i.e. vegetarian vs vegan vs has meat)
control_description: Participants saw menu options with a "(vegan)" or "(vegetarian)" label shown in the title of option 1; the choice questions differ in the types of options compared (i.e. vegetarian vs vegan vs has meat)
sample_description: US Prolific workers over the age of 18 and lived in one of the following US states when signing up on the Prolific platform: Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine, Vermont, Connecticut, and New York
outcome_description: Percentage of option 1 chosen which is a vegetarian option (as compared to option 2, which was meat)

outcome_description: Percentage of option 1 chosen which was a vegan option (as compared to option 1, which was meat)

paper_authors: McDonough, T.
paper_title: Modifying Students’ Intentions to Eat Sustainably
intervention_description: A survey of pre-validated measures was administered following exposure to the campaign to assess change in: fruit and vegetable intake, intentions, attitudes, perceived behavioral control, and subjective norms
control_description: A survey of pre-validated measures was administered prior to, and following exposure to the campaign to assess change in: fruit and vegetable intake, intentions, attitudes, perceived behavioral control, and subjective norms
sample_description: McGill University students
outcome_description: Mean score for survey questions regarding the intentions to eat meatless meals which is measured via a Likert scale (1-5). (e.g. Item 37 - I intend to eat meatless meals more often)

paper_title: The effect of information nudges on online purchases of meat alternatives
intervention_description: Next to the meat and plant-based alternatives, there was a health message emphasizing the health benefits of consuming less meat: “To reduce your risk of diabetes by 40%, eat one less serving of meat every day"

sample_description: respondents recruited on campus of an American university and via the university email

paper_title: The effect of information nudges on online purchases of meat alternatives

control_description: Participants were presented with a shopping list consisting of meat and plant-based meat alternatives during an online grocery shopping task
sample_description: respondents recruited on campus of an American university and via the university email
outcome_description: Proportion of plant-based meat purchases

paper_authors: De-loyde, K.; Pilling, M. A.; Thornton, A.; Spencer, G.; Maynard, O. M.
paper_title: Promoting sustainable diets using eco-labelling and social nudges: A randomised online experiment
intervention_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito, alongside a traffic light system, with a scale of 1–5, which was circled at the appropriate sustainability level for that burrito: beef burrito – unsustainable, chicken burrito – neither sustainable nor unsustainable and vegetarian burrito – sustainable
control_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito
sample_description: UK Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the vegetarian burrito option

paper_authors: De-loyde, K.; Pilling, M. A.; Thornton, A.; Spencer, G.; Maynard, O. M.
paper_title: Promoting sustainable diets using eco-labelling and social nudges: A randomised online experiment
intervention_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito, where the vegetarian burrito was presented alongside a popularity label consisting of a gold star next to the words ‘Most Popular’
control_description: Participants were shown a menu with a beef burrito, a chicken burrito and a vegetarian burrito
sample_description: UK Prolific workers
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the vegetarian burrito option

paper_authors: Van Loo, Ellen J.; Caputo, Vincenzina; Lusk, Jayson L.
paper_title: Consumer Preferences for Farm-Raised Meat, Lab-Grown Meat, and Plant-Based Meat Alternatives: Does Information or Brand Matter?
intervention_description: Participants were shown environmental information that originated from the companies selling these products (i.e. reduction in water use, land use, energy use and greenhouse gas emissions associated to each of the three beef alternatives compared to conventional beef)
control_description: Participants were asked to choose between lab-grown beef, plant-based meat animal-like heme protein, plant-based meat using pea protein, and farm-raised beef, with no additional information given about the products
sample_description: U.S. food shoppers were recruited by a market research agency, considering quotas for regions, gender, and race and ethnicity
outcome_description: Percentage of beef item chosen

intervention_description: Participants were presented with a menu with a vegetarian default black bean burger, with a separate box stating “Would you rather have a Classic Burger? – Ask the waiter”

paper_authors: Lange, Florian; Cnudde, Marjolein; Maesen, Hannah
paper_title: Using prosocial incentives to promote vegetarian food choices: A field experiment
intervention_description: Participants saw posters in the restaurant. Posters included an earth image, emphasizing there is no other planet, and a text suggesting them to eat vegetarian if they want to save the planet. Additionally, this poster indicated that for every vegetarian order there will be a tree donation to Eden reforestation projects.
sample_description: Customers of a pasta restaurant in the city center of a Belgian University town
outcome_description: The percentage of vegetarian dishes chosen by the customers

paper_title: Meating Conflict: Toward a Model of Ambivalence-Motivated Reduction of Meat Consumption
intervention_description: To make participants to reflect on their inconsistent evaluations about meat, they were asked to describe two personally held reactions in favor of and two reactions opposed to meat consumption or vaccination in the control group.
control_description: Participants assigned to a task about an unrelated control topic (going to the cinema)
sample_description: MTurk Participants mainly from North America (90%), and more than half of them had university degrees.
outcome_description: Participants' intention to reduce meat consumption, in this case, it was measured with a 2 item scale - the future consumption was mentioned to be next week

outcome_description: Percentage of participants who selected a vegetarian main course

outcome_description: Percentage of participants who selected a vegetarian main course

paper_authors: Brachem, J.; Krüdewagen, H.; Hagmayer, Y.
paper_title: The Limits of Nudging: Can Descriptive Social Norms be Used to Reduce Meat Consumption? It's Probably Not That Easy
intervention_description: Participants saw descriptive social norm message e.g. “Between 2010 and 2017, the share of vegetarian and vegan meals in our sales rose from about 24% to more than 35%.” in between a series of menu choices
control_description: Participants saw attentional control messages e.g. “All side dishes in our canteens are either vegetarian or vegan." in between a series of menu choices
sample_description: Predominantly university students recruited through posts in social media groups associated with the University of Göttingen, Germany
outcome_description: Percentage of a vegetarian or vegan meal chosen from the menu

paper_title: Ninety Minutes to Reduce One's Intention to Eat Meat: A Preliminary Experimental Investigation on the Effect of Watching the Cowspiracy Documentary on Intention to Reduce Meat Consumption
intervention_description: Participants watched a video-documentary about the environmental impact of meat production, Cowspiracy, and filled in a questionnaire pre and post-documentary
control_description: Participants watched the nature documentary, “Planet Earth” (2006) about environmental change, where no reference to meat consumption was made, and filled in a questionnaire pre and post-documentary
sample_description: Young adults who consumed meat almost on a daily basis recruited via flyers, social media, and e-mail
outcome_description: Attitudes towards meat reduction

paper_title: The ABC’s of Ecological and Nutrition Labels. The Impact of Label Theme and Complexity on the Environmental Footprint of Online Grocery Choices

paper_authors: Abrahamse, W.; Steg, L.; Vlek, C.; Rothengatter, T.
paper_title: The effect of tailored information, goal setting, and tailored feedback on household energy use, energy-related behaviors, and behavioral antecedents
intervention_description: Two groups of households received tailored energy-saving information, including details about global warming and energy costs, plus a personalized list of relevant energy-saving measures. Both groups were asked to achieve a 5% energy reduction and received individual feedback via a website showing their percentage energy savings, the contribution of each behavior, and money saved. The first group received only individual goals and feedback, while the second group also received a collective 5% group goal and monthly feedback about the group's average and total energy savings via newsletter.
sample_description: households from Groningen, the Netherlands
outcome_description: Meat consumption per meal

paper_authors: Abrahamse, W.; Steg, L.; Vlek, C.; Rothengatter, T.
paper_title: The effect of tailored information, goal setting, and tailored feedback on household energy use, energy-related behaviors, and behavioral antecedents

The first group received only individual goals and feedback, while the second group also received a collective 5% group goal and monthly feedback about the group's average and total energy savings via newsletter.
sample_description: households from Groningen, the Netherlands
outcome_description: Meat consumption per meal

paper_authors: Acharya, S.; Maskarinec, G.; Williams, A. E.; Oshiro, C.; Hebshi, S.; Murphy, P.
paper_title: Nutritional changes among premenopausal women undertaking a soya based dietary intervention study in Hawaii
paper_source: Journal of Human Nutrition and Dietetics
intervention_description: Regular supplies of soya foods were given free-of-charge to the intervention group. Based on individual preferences, the study dietitian made speciﬁc suggestions on how to incorporate soya foods into the daily menu, such as replacing meat with tofu in stew or fried dishes, cow milk with soyamilk, and cookies with a soya protein bar. To avoid weight gain, replacing other foods was emphasized over adding soya foods. To maintain compliance, all participants received individual dietary counselling by a registered dietitian and follow-up phone calls. They had at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.
control_description: Women in the control group had, like in the experimental group, at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.
sample_description: Women between 35 and 46 years with low soya intake, a normal mammogram, regular menstrual cycles, and an intact uterus, from Hawaii.
outcome_description: Total dairy servings consumed during the previous day
