paper_authors: Hope, J. E.; Green, S. A.; Peacock, J. R.; Mathur, M.
paper_title: Taking a bite out of meat, or just giving fresh veggies the boot? Plant-based meats did not reduce meat purchasing in a randomized controlled menu intervention
intervention_description: Sofritas and veggie options were kept, and a fictional PMA designated “chick’nitas” was added, giving participants three non meat options including two PMAs
control_description: The online Chipotle menu (August 2024) was duplicated, and participants had the same two non-meat options avaliable to real Chipotle diners.
sample_description: Adults fluent in English and residing in the U.S recruited via Prolific
outcome_description: Primary dependent variable was taco filling selection: chicken, steak, beef barbacoa, carnitas, vegetables and guacamole, sofritas, chick’nitas, no protein, or no taco at all.

paper_authors: dos Santos, Q.; Perez-Cueto, F.J.A.; Rodrigues, V.M.; Appleton, K.; Giboreau, A.; Saulais, L.; Monteleone, E.
paper_title: Impact of a nudging intervention and factors associated with vegetable dish choice among european adolescents
intervention_description: Participants were asked to choose between three meals, based, respectively, on Meat balls, Veggie balls and Fish cakes. All three dishes were labelled with their names, but the Veggie balls were presented as the “dish of the day”. The vegetable-based dish was both labelled as “dish of the day”, and orally informed by foodservice employees as being the “dish of the day” in all countries with the following phrase: “Welcome! Today we have Veggie balls as dish of the day” (verbal prompt).
control_description: The three identical dishes to the intervention condition were just labelled with their names and no “dish of the day” was offered
sample_description: European adolescents from Denmark, France, Italy and the UK
outcome_description: Proportion of veggie balls dish chosen

paper_authors: Lane, H.; Pokutnia, O.; Walker, M. D.; Farias, A. R.
paper_title: Carbon labeling on meals in a ferry canteen
intervention_description: Carbon labeling is added next to the meals (low/medium/high CO2 emissions), with a screen explaining the labeling next to the checkout tiles
control_description: Only the price and name of the meal were visible to the patrons in the canteen
sample_description: datapoint represents purchases made in the canteen of a ferry going between Helsingborg in Sweden and Helsingør in Denmark
outcome_description: Percentage of vegetarian portions shared

paper_authors: Katare, B.; Yim, H.; Byrne, A.; Wang, H. H.; Wetzstein, N.
paper_title: Consumer willingness to pay for environmentally sustainable meat and a plant-based meat substitute
intervention_description: Control group were not provided any information prior to their bidding.
control_description: Treatment group was presented with information regarding the health and environmental benefits of consuming a plant-based meat substitute versus beef prior to bidding
sample_description: US Large scale university students
outcome_description: The amount of money (premium) a participant is willing to pay to replace their endowed 6-oz. sliced deli beef with 6 oz. of sustainably produced beef.

paper_authors: Scharmer, A.
paper_title: For the Planet, the Animals, or Oneself? Measuring Individuals’ Motivations to Restrict Meat Consumption and Encouraging Dietary Change
intervention_description: Participants are presented with a 120-word message designed to encompass four distinct motivational factors. In this condition, the message is specifically framed around the theme of animal welfare. (e.g. positive outcomes for animal welfare)
control_description: No message - control condition.
sample_description: Participants all resided in the United States and in response to a screening question about dietary restrictions, they did not indicate that they followed a vegan or vegetarian diet
outcome_description: Participants answered a single item about their intentions to reduce their meat consumption

outcome_description: Participants answered a single item about their intentions to reduce their meat consumption

paper_authors: Schwantes, C.
paper_title: The Meat of the Matter: Using Social Marketing to Influence Red Meat Purchase Behaviour
intervention_description: Customers entering the intervention store were asked the following question: “To consider a healthy and sustainable lifestyle, would you be interested in reducing your red meat purchases by one meal per week?” If customers agreed, they were asked to demonstrate their commitment by having their name listed on the public-facing project website, www.meatofthematerstudy.squarespace.com. They were also given a small business card with the project website to see their name and learn more about the study.
sample_description: shoppers at a grocery store
outcome_description: Amount of red meat purchased at the grocery store on average

paper_authors: Marette, Stéphan; Roosen, Jutta; Blanchemanche, Sandrine
paper_title: Health information and substitution between fish: Lessons from laboratory and field experiments
intervention_description: Participants received a message based on advisories provided by health agencies, revealing health information about the risks and benefits of fish consumption; this was read out loud to them and they received a brochure with the same information
sample_description: households with (i) at least one woman between 25 and 35 years of age, (ii) at least one child under 15 and (iii) who consume fish at least twice a week
outcome_label: all fish and sea foods consumption
outcome_description: Average values of the weekly serving frequency of all fish and sea foods for all women participating

paper_authors: Wolfson, Julia A; Musicus, Aviva A; Leung, Cindy W; Gearhardt, Ashley N; Falbe, Jennifer
paper_title: Effect of Climate Change Impact Menu Labels on Fast Food Ordering Choices Among US Adults: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
intervention_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with green low–climate impact labels on chicken, fish, or vegetarian items (positive framing); The top of each menu featured a disclosure statement explaining the label’s meaning: “This item is environmentally sustainable. It has low greenhouse gas emissions and a low contribution to climate change.”
control_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with QR code labels on all items
sample_description: respondents recruited from the National Opinion Research Center (NORC) AmeriSpeak panel
outcome_description: Predicted probability of selecting the Impossible burger (which is the plant-based burger)

paper_authors: Wolfson, Julia A; Musicus, Aviva A; Leung, Cindy W; Gearhardt, Ashley N; Falbe, Jennifer
paper_title: Effect of Climate Change Impact Menu Labels on Fast Food Ordering Choices Among US Adults: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
intervention_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with green low–climate impact labels on chicken, fish, or vegetarian items (positive framing); The top of each menu featured a disclosure statement explaining the label’s meaning: “This item is environmentally sustainable. control_description: Participants were shown a fast food restaurant menu with QR code labels on all items
sample_description: respondents recruited from the National Opinion Research Center (NORC) AmeriSpeak panel
outcome_description: Predicted probability of selecting the salad option

sample_description: respondents recruited from the National Opinion Research Center (NORC) AmeriSpeak panel
outcome_description: Predicted probability of selecting the Impossible burger (which is the plant-based burger)

paper_authors: Carfora, Valentina; Catellani, Patrizia
paper_title: Legumes or Meat? The Effectiveness of Recommendation Messages towards a Plant-Based Diet Depends on People’s Identification with Flexitarians
intervention_description: Every day at 9:30 and for 14 days (between T1 and T2), participants received one message per day, focused on the lower environmental impact of cultivating legumes than producing meat (e.g., “Compared to livestock feeding production, legume cultivation requires a limited use of fertilizers. Thus, it has a lower pollution impact. If you eat legumes rather than meat, you protect the planet from pollution”)
control_description: Participants did not receive any messages
sample_description: Italian adults recruited by the university app
outcome_description: Consumption of red, processed, and white meat over the previous week

paper_authors: Carfora, Valentina; Catellani, Patrizia

intervention_description: Every day at 9:30 and for 14 days (between T1 and T2), participants received replacement messages combined with a reference to the dynamic norm (e.g., “Nowadays, more and more people eat legumes instead of meat. paper_authors: Dannenberg, A.; Weingärtner, E.
paper_title: The Effects of Observability and an Information Nudge on Food Choice
intervention_description: Participants read the following information on meat consumption reduction: "Reducing one's consumption of animal products can have significant environmental benefits. For example, food-related greenhouse gas emissions can on average be lowered by about a quarter (24%) through following a vegetarian diet and by about half (53%) through following a vegan diet." before privately announced their choice of voucher
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."
sample_description: Bachelor and Master students who were having an online lecture at a university in Germany
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the voucher for a meat sandwich

paper_authors: Dannenberg, A.; Weingärtner, E.
paper_title: The Effects of Observability and an Information Nudge on Food Choice
intervention_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room and asked for their choice of voucher so that we can pass on the selection to the restaurant. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."
sample_description: Bachelor and Master students who were having an online lecture at a university in Germany
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the voucher for a meat sandwich

For example, food-related greenhouse gas emissions can on average be lowered by about a quarter (24%) through following a vegetarian diet and by about half (53%) through following a vegan diet." before their choice of voucher was publicly announced
control_description: No information on meat consumption were given, participants read the following text just before they made their decision on which sandwich they wanted (meat, vegetarian or vegan): "The winners will be publicly announced directly in the breakout room. Their choice of voucher will not be revealed to other participants. Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."
sample_description: Bachelor and Master students who were having an online lecture at a university in Germany
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the voucher for a meat sandwich

paper_authors: Flynn, Mary M.; Reinert, Steven E.; Schiff, Andrew R.
paper_title: A Six-Week Cooking Program of Plant-Based Recipes Improves Food Security, Body Weight, and Food Purchases for Food Pantry Clients
intervention_description: Participants participated in a 6-week cooking class in which they observed the preparation of a plant-based, olive oil diet meal and got to taste test; While the recipe was being prepared, the staff discussed consistent themes each week, including the health benefits of extra virgin olive oil and encouraging the participants to use olive oil to cook their vegetables; meat/poultry/seafood is not needed daily; vegetables and all starch products (including beans) contain protein. No other nutrition- or food-related information was provided. All of the recipes were made with extra virgin olive oil (1 to 2 tablespoons), contained on average 2 servings of vegetables, and did not contain meat/poultry or seafood
sample_description: food pantry clients
outcome_description: Number of reported meals per week that were plant based recipes using olive oil for cooking and did not contain meat/poultry/seafood

paper_authors: Hansen, Pelle G; Schilling, Mathilde; Malthesen, Mia S
paper_title: Nudging healthy and sustainable food choices: three randomized controlled field experiments using a vegetarian lunch-default as a normative signal
intervention_description: Participants received a registration presenting a vegetarian buffet as the default, allowing the active choice of a non-vegetarian option
control_description: Participants received a standard lunch registration presenting a non-vegetarian buffet as the default, but allowing the active choice of a vegetarian option
sample_description: politicians, decision makers, organizations, and staff representatives within public health who attended the 'Citizens expectations about and behaviour relative to the national health services' conference
outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the vegetarian option for lunch
